body:
A very good question! 

Short answer - you can't at the moment. 

It is probably essential if you are working with case insensitive file systems though. 

Easy would be to add a flag say `--filters-case-insensitive` which makes all filters/globs case insensitive (rsync doesn't have such an option) or `--case-insensitive-globs`

Harder would be to make it settable for each glob. There are some ideas here: http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/48770/how-to-match-case-insensitive-patterns-with-ls

What do you think?
I think I'm just going to have to deal with "[Jj][Pp][Gg]" for now. ;-)

:-)

I'm going to re-open this as I'd quite like to add the flag option at some point!

Why not use something similar to find? Prepend 'i' in the flag name to indicate that it's case insensitive:

`-name "FooBar"` vs `-iname "FooBar"`

how would the -name/-iname function work with Rclone? I don't see that making sense without restructuring the way Rclone works.

ncw's suggestion of `--filters-case-insensitive` flag makes more sense.

Looking forward to this.

issue.title: case insensitive from filtering

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body: would it be possible to have a flag for filtering exclude with case insensitive?

body:
The flag isn't very robust though.  Its all or nothing.  It would have been better to have the case sensitivity within each include/exclude. 

Perhaps within the 'filter' flags only something like this gets implemented:
--filter "+i file.JpG" 

where the i represents that line is case insensitive.  That would also allow building more flags unto each rule in the future if required.

@ncw If the underlying file-system is case-insensitive then it never makes sense to use case-sensitive filtering. On Windows, I believe the FS is always case-insensitive. On Mac, I forget whether case-sensitivity is system-wide or on a per-drive basis.

In any case, I suggest that rclone detect whether the FS is case-insensitive and in such cases always interpret filters applied on it as case-insensitive (no flags required).

@cowwoc 
> In any case, I suggest that rclone detect whether the FS is case-insensitive and in such cases always interpret filters applied on it as case-insensitive (no flags required).

Alas it is impossible to guess, the only way to be sure is to write a file.
.
That said rclone knows pretty accurately whether a backend is case insensitive or not...

I've implemented the `--ignore-case` flag here:

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.44-080-g16f797a7-ignore-case-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)
This is now merged to master and will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) in 15-30 mins.  It will be released in v1.45.
